articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record, both globally and in Europe. South-East Europe is among the most climate-vulnerable regions of the continent, with temperatures rising at twice the global average. Coastal areas, including the Adriatic coast, are increasingly at risk due to rising sea levels, leading to greater threats of flooding and infrastructure damage.

articles.title: Great Lakes ice cover off to fast start
articles.author: Colton Cichoracki
articles.summary: The total ice cover on the Great Lakes was 27% as of Feb. 6. The ice fishing industry has been off to a fast start on Great Lakes and inland lakes. The weather pattern in February is expected to be cold but not as cold as January was.

articles.title: Cold stun kills fish across Eastern Carolina
articles.author: WITN Web Team
articles.summary: Some coastal areas across Eastern Carolina are dealing with fish kills. North Carolina Marine Fisheries closed coastal and joint waters in North Carolina to commercial and recreational spotted seatrout harvest from Friday, January 24th until the spring due to the cold stun event. Speckled trout off of Whichards Beach Road in Beaufort County died.

articles.title: 75pc believe climate change deprioritised: survey
articles.author: Zaki Abbas
articles.summary: A survey by Ipsos with a sample size of over 1,500 participants launched at the Breathe Pakistan conference revealed that only 31% of Pakistanis believe the environment is at a critical stage requiring urgent action. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa showed the highest urgency with 48% people being concerned in the province.

articles.title: Women bear the brunt of environmental disasters: Jane Marriott
articles.author: Jamal Shahid
articles.summary: UK High Commissioner to Pakistan Jane Marriott delivered the keynote address at Breathe Pakistan conference on empowering women to fight climate change. 80 per cent of people displaced by climate change are women. Women and children are 14 times more likely to die in climate-related disasters than men.

articles.title: Blazes Continue to Cause Closure of Popular Hike Track
articles.author: AAP
articles.summary: Tasmanian authorities have extended the closure of the Overland Track until Feb. 23 due to a fire at Canning Peak near Cradle Mountain in the state's central highlands. Dry lighting sparked the blaze on Feb. 3. The fire spread in the direction of the 65-kilometre, multi-day trail in the World Heritage Wilderness Area. The extended closure is a result of challenging fire conditions which are expected to continue into next week.

articles.title: Blessing the ‘birds' critical to saving Kauaʻi forest birds : Maui Now
articles.summary: Helicopters from Jack Harter Helicopters helped to bless the Kaua'i Forest Bird Recovery Project at Kōkeʻe, near the Alaka'i Plateau on Monday. The project has worked to save the island's native forest birds from extinction for nearly 20 years. They need helicopters for a two-pronged mosquito control effort in the mountains, where forest bird populations have been decimated by avian malaria.

articles.title: Hottest January on the Books Stumps Scientists
articles.author: Jenn Gidman
articles.summary: The world warmed to another monthly heat record in January despite an abnormally chilly US, a cooling La Nina and predictions of a slightly less-hot 2025 per European climate service Copernicus. The January heat record coincides with a new study by a new research group.

articles.title: Extreme Arctic Warming Sees North Pole Temperatures Rise Above Freezing
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: There was a rise in Arctic temperatures 20 degrees Celsius above normal at the North Pole. Scientists warn of accelerating ice loss and climate change impacts as a result of the event. The event has been described as a "major weather event".

articles.title: EXCLUSIVE: Sensational Findings Point to Hunga Tonga Eruption as Prime Suspect Behind Recent Temperature Spike
articles.author: The Daily Sceptic
articles.summary: In January 2022, Hunga Tonga erupted and shot so much water into the upper atmosphere that levels in the stratosphere rose suddenly by at least 10%. It was a genuine one in 100, or 200 year event and was reasonably expected to produce temporary weather changes around the globe.

articles.title: Speakers warn of danger posed by climate change to agriculture
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Climate change is threatening agricultural production in Pakistan. Pakistan needs to rethink current practices and follow adaptation practices to enhance productivity, says a senior government official at the 'Breathe Pakistan' international climate change conference. Pakistan is already in a crisis situation and does not have time to make plans to deal with this situation.

articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin travels to Western North Carolina to visit communities rebuilding in the wake of Hurricane Helene on February 7, 2025. EPA Press Office (press@epa.gov) is the official contact for the EPA press office on Friday, 7 February 2025.

articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Rising sea levels threaten an indigenous group's home in Panama. Not everyone wants to leave, though.      Â   in this case, the indigenous people do not want to leave their homes, however.  in the case of this indigenous group, they want to stay.

articles.title: KILGORE'S CORNER: Almost time to land some lunkers
articles.author: Muskogee Phoenix
articles.summary: The recent warm up in temperatures prompted Punxsutawney to get up out of the recliner and off his duff. There was a record breaking spike in above average temperatures for the month of February earlier this week. Punxsuttawney wouldn't believe it.

articles.title: Britain has a new snake species—should climate change mean it is allowed to stay?
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: All animals live in or seek a set of climate conditions they find tolerable. The existence of many species now rests on the outcome of human-driven climate change. Rising temperatures are moving the available climate niches of some species, which is bad for them.

articles.title: 97 school days lost in 2023-24 due to climate disruptions in Pakistan
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Climate change has disrupted education worldwide. Students in Pakistan lose 97 school days between 2023 and 2024 due to climate change, 54 per cent of a typical academic year. Panel discussion was titled "Climate Education: Safeguarding and Empowering Children and Youth in a Changing World".

articles.title: SCCI wants joint initiatives to cope with climate change issues
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Sarhad Chamber of Commerce and Industry President, Fazal Moqeem Khan, said January of the current year had remained very hot, a major indication of rising impacts of climate change. He urged joint initiatives and plantations to cope with the situation.

articles.title: Climate change: The Panama community that fled its drowning island
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Rising sea levels threaten an indigenous group's way of life, according to the UNICEF. The group is called the Yurok people.   Â   yurok means "people of the sea" in Yurocan language.

articles.title: Multi-million dollar project launched in Belize to boost sugarcane resilience
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre (CCCCC) and the Government of Belize launched the Building the Adaptive Capacity of Sugarcane Farmers in Northern Belize (BAC-SuF) project. This is a first-time initiative for the Government.

articles.title: Crevasses in Greenland's ice sheet are increasing, study shows
articles.author: Fast Company
articles.summary: Observing Greenland from a helicopter is difficult because of the scale of the icebergs the size of office blocks.    The helicopter was flying over the waves of a fjord before noticing the tiny shadow of a seabird far below and realizing it was icebergs.

articles.title: The Future of Sea Level Rise
articles.author: Dissident Voice
articles.summary: In the next decade or two the world will be completely different, according to PM Margaret Thatcher's 1989 speech to the UN General Assembly. The lesson of these Polar processes is that an environmental or climatic change produced by man may take on a self-sustaining or 'runaway' quality.

articles.title: Backyard count is everyone's bird census
articles.author: Betsy Bloom
articles.summary: The 28th-annual Great Backyard Bird Count is set for Friday, February 14th through Monday, February 17th. It's an inter-organizational effort between the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, National Audubon Society and Birds Canada. Participants spend at least 15 minutes on one or more of the four days noting each bird species and numbers seen. The data can be entered at https://www.birdcount.org.
